image.altText: A grapic depicting a computer infected with malware for a story about stolen banking passwords.

props.synopsis: The banking passwords of tens of of thousands of Australians have been stolen using malware and traded online by cybercriminals, the ABC can reveal.

title.children: Banking passwords stolen from thousands of Australians and traded online

image.altText: Peter Dutton, wearing a navy suit jacket with pale blue shirt and lilac tie, speaks in front of blue corflute

props.synopsis: Crime and policing are state issues, but with recent polling showing it's top of mind for some voters, could it sway federal election votes?

title.children: Dutton is campaigning on crime. In some seats voters say it's a top concern

image.altText: A man standing with a sliding door slightly open looks at the camera as a woman stands in front of him.

props.synopsis: The former operator of a Sydney childcare centre where children were force-fed until they vomited, strapped in highchairs for hours and had their heads shoved into garbage bins, has been permanently banned from working in the disability support sector.

title.children: 'House of horrors' childcare owner banned from NDIS

image.altText: Side profile of Donald Trump in a white baseball cap

props.synopsis: In Donald Trump's world, deficits are always bad and surpluses are always good. In isolation, it's an easy concept to sell to a deeply divided nation. But it ignores how the US economy has powered its way to global domination.

title.children: The three things eluding Trump on trade

image.altText: Canada's Prime Minister Mark Carney gestures as he speaks into a microphone during a campaign event.

props.synopsis: Canadians are at the polls, with the ruling Liberal Party favoured to stay in power after an extraordinary surge in support following Donald Trump's return to the US presidency.

title.children: 'I don't know if he would look to invade': Canadians vote with Trump in mind

image.altText: Miguel Villadiego at the cemetery in Tierralta.

props.synopsis: Decades of violence have left over a hundred thousand missing in Colombia. The country has made it its mission to find them.

title.children: In Colombia, 120,000 people have vanished. This CSI unit is finding them

image.altText: A close up composite photo of Peter Dutton and Anthony Albanese at the debate.

props.synopsis: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has called out Peter Dutton's history of "punching down on vulnerable people" during a wide-ranging interview on 7.30 that focused on several key election issues.

title.children: 'Darkened his own brand': Albanese lashes Dutton's leadership style

image.altText: Two senior men sitting together, smiling.

props.synopsis: The federal seat of Bass is held by a margin of just 1.4 per cent. For these older voters who live in the electorate, health, climate and community sport are the issues that will decide their vote.

title.children: In this marginal Tasmanian seat, this is what older voters care about

image.altText: A compilation photo of Allegra Spender, Alex Dyson, Kate Chaney and Zoe Daniel.

props.synopsis: Political funding body Climate 200 is bankrolling up to 75 per cent of campaign costs for several independent candidates this election.

title.children: How much Climate 200 has donated to 19 independent candidates

image.altText: An army tank firing flames.

props.synopsis: A fleet of retired tanks the Albanese government pledged to Ukraine last year remain stuck in Australia, with defence figures in part blaming resistance from the United States for their delayed transfer.

title.children: Aging army tanks donated to Ukraine are yet to leave Australia

image.altText: Anthony Albanese

props.synopsis: With Australian voters facing an increasingly dangerous and uncertain world, both Labor and the Coalition are trying to burnish their national security credentials.

title.children: How anxieties about national security could shape the election outcome

image.altText: A crowd of people in the dark

props.synopsis: Authorities say it could take hours or even days to fully restore power to more than 60 million people.

title.children: Major power cuts in Spain and Portugal caused by 'extreme temperature' changes

image.altText: Indian Sheik man in his home who talks to ABC News about building woes

props.synopsis: Builders take out insurance designed to cover clients' costs in the event they go bust. But some people are waiting for years for a payout and facing potential bankruptcy.

title.children: Calls grow for greater consumer protection as more builders go bust

image.altText: A composite image of three men

props.synopsis: Donald Trump says Ukraine is prepared to give up Crimea, territory that Russia annexed after 2014. So what do both sides of the conflict want to see before ending the war?

title.children: As Putin signals a three-day ceasefire, what are Kyiv and Moscow's demands?

image.altText: A head of a cardinal wearing a red cap

props.synopsis: Cardinals will meet in a secret conclave to elect the new leader of the Catholic Church starting from May 7, the Vatican has confirmed.

title.children: Conclave to pick new pope to start next week, Vatican confirms

image.altText: A woman cries in front of a car.

props.synopsis: The murder trial of Erin Patterson over an allegedly poisonous mushroom meal is set to begin, nearly two years on from when three people died after eating a beef Wellington.

title.children: Erin Patterson's triple-murder trial begins today

image.altText: A drawing of a small, platypus-like creature in the water.

props.synopsis: A study of a 100 million-year-old bone suggests the ancient relative of the echidna and the platypus was semiaquatic — and echidnas moved back to the land from the water as they evolved.

title.children: Fossil clue suggests echidna ancestors lived in water like platypus

image.altText: Tony Albert smiles with arms crossed across chest. He wears bright purple shirt and blurred window is behind him.

props.synopsis: Tony Albert, one of Australia's most awarded and recognised contemporary artists, tells Virginia Trioli about seeking out "Aboriginalia" to remove it from circulation, and to give it new voice.

title.children: The artist on a mission to take these racist items out of circulation

image.altText: Female Victoria Police officer with her back to camera.

props.synopsis: Three years after Victoria Police stood up a new unit to investigate family violence by serving officers, women say they've faced shocking treatment and even criminal charges themselves after gathering the courage to report abuse.

title.children: A new unit targeted abusive cops. Three years on, victims feel betrayed

image.altText: A woman with a blonde bob, smiling alongside her young family.

props.synopsis: The drug, given as an injection under the skin, combines fragments of a protein found in the beta cells of people with type 1 diabetes and vitamin D to calm the immune response.

title.children: World-first diabetes drug trial aims to reprogram immune system

image.altText: A conical mountain capped with snow rises from clouds.

props.synopsis: The man reportedly returned to the mountain to get his phone days after the first rescue.

title.children: Man rescued twice in one week from Mount Fuji

image.altText: Albanese speaking makes a thumb pointing backwards gesture

props.synopsis: High-stake election campaigns and high school popularity politics have a lot more in common than you'd hope for grown men vying to run the country.

title.children: Could Trump really not own a mobile phone? Albanese's claim doesn't stack up

image.altText: Two workers in hi-vis outfits install solar panels on a tiled roof of an apartment building.

props.synopsis: Apartment-owners across the state can now access government grants to offset half the cost of new rooftop solar systems, filling in a major gap in coverage on units.

title.children: The new technology making it cheaper to add solar panels to units

image.altText: A close-up of Jim Chalmers in front of a black background.

props.synopsis: Treasurer Jim Chalmers says the federal budget will be about $1 billion better off over four years compared to the March budget.

title.children: Labor demands Coalition costings and claims $1b in deficit reduction

image.altText: Donald trump standing in front of the american flag

props.synopsis: After the resignation of Justin Trudeau, it was unlikely that Canada's governing Liberal party would secure another term when Canadians went to the polls — then Donald Trump's tariffs hit the country.

title.children: 'Our heads are spinning': Has Trump secured another term for Canada's 'unpopular' government?

image.altText: Sheikh Wesam Charkawi Muslim Vote convener

props.synopsis: The Muslim Vote campaign has taken aim at the Labor Party's "failure to stand for justice on Gaza and Palestine" as it looks to unseat Parramatta MP Andrew Charlton.

title.children: Muslim Vote urges Parramatta constituents to preference Libs over Labor

image.altText: a man being carried after strike hit detention centre in Yemen

props.synopsis: Yemen's Iran-aligned Houthis has alleged that a US air strike has hit a detention centre in Saada that holds African migrants.

title.children: Houthi rebels say 68 killed by US air strike that hit Yemen detention centre

image.altText: Adonis Quita (middle) who witnessed the event, sings during a worship service.

props.synopsis: Witnesses at the scene of a deadly car ramming in Vancouver detail the incident, as the death toll continues to climb.

title.children: Witnesses recount deadly Vancouver car ramming attack

image.altText: The facade of a new police station in Darwin's northern suburbs

props.synopsis: The unstaffed Nightcliff Police Station stands opposite to where 71-year-old supermarket owner Linford Feick was fatally stabbed last week.

title.children: Concerns over $12m 'white elephant' police station opposite fatal stabbing site

image.altText: Peter Dutton, wearing a suit and tie, opens his mouth to speak, standing outdoors with trees behind him.

props.synopsis: A Four Corners investigation finds Opposition Leader Peter Dutton failed to disclose his interest in a family trust for two years.

title.children: Business records reveal new details of Dutton family's childcare millions

image.altText: Referee Wyatt Raymond gestures with his hand as Warriors and Knights players look on during an NRL game.

props.synopsis: Round eight of the NRL saw 18 players sin-binned as the league cracked down on high tackles. But it has left many players, coaches, fans and experts scratching their heads.

title.children: 'It's a disaster': How the NRL world reacted as high-tackle drama rolls on

image.altText: A photo of China's crewed submersible, the Fendhouze, held aloft above the water before going in.

props.synopsis: China's new cable cutter has been making headlines, but how much of a threat is it really?

title.children: What China's new cable-cutter signals for Australia

image.altText: Woman stands in courtroom, woman in road in top left-hand corner

props.synopsis: The opening day of the inquest has been told there was evidence of "rudimentary planning" and in the years prior Joel Cauchi had purchased knives which were used on the day of the attack that killed six people.

title.children: Internet history reveals Bondi Junction killer was 'planning a strike', inquest told

image.altText: Two Indigenous men stand on a smoky stage, one playing a didgeridoo and the other dressed in traditional dress

props.synopsis: Opposition Leader Peter Dutton suggests Anzac Day dawn services should not involve Welcome to Country ceremonies and says most veterans do not support having them at the events.

title.children: Dutton suggests Anzac Day services should not involve Welcomes to Country

image.altText: Peter Dutton and Anthony Albanese smiling on rainbow background.

props.synopsis: While there is broad agreement that Peter Dutton has a narrower path to victory than Anthony Albanese, campaigners are bracing for the unexpected.

title.children: Here's the state of play in dozens of seats that could decide the election
